computer.description:
The TRS-80 model 4 (ref 26-1068/69) was one of the last models of the TRS-80 series (and perhaps the less known). It ran at 4 MHz and displayed 80 columns x 24 lines in Model 4 mode, but was fully compatible with the TRS-80 model 3 and in Model 3 mode actually displayed 64x16 and ran at the Model 3's 2 MHz.
It had 64 or 128 KB RAM, the 64 upper KB being used as a ram disk. It had one or two 5.25" floppy disk (184 KB each) and ran under TRSDOS 6.0 or 1.3, LDOS or CP/M.
A transformation kit "TRS80 model III -> model IV" was available.
The Model 4 was followed by the Model 4D (ref. 26-1070). The only difference being double sided drives -384 KB, instead of single sided drives.
A portable version of the Model IV called Model 4P (ref. 26-1080) was also marketed few time after. _______________________

emulator.description: This program emulates a complete TRS-80
emulator.name: David Keil's TRS-80 Model III/4/4P Emulator Page

emulator.description: This TRS-80 Model III/4 Emulator is a commercial product
emulator.name: TRS-80 Model III/4 Emulator

emulator.description: xtrs is a Radio Shack TRS-80 Model I/III/4/4P emulator for Unix and the X Window System
emulator.name: xtrs: TRS-80 Model I/III/4 Emulator for Unix

emulator.description: With this Java emulator, you'll be able to write a BASIC program directly in your browser!
emulator.name: TRS-80 Level I BASIC in a browser

emulator.description: A complete list of TRS-80 emulators for various platforms !
emulator.name: Ira Goldklang's TRS-80 Revived Pages

emulator.description: MESS emulator also emulates a TRS-80 systems
emulator.name: MESS

item.description: Remote Unit Active|||Serial# 26-1210|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;REMOTE UNIT ACTIVE</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Serial# 26-1210</strong><br><blockquote>This rare unit is meant for teachers to control up to 16 TRS-80 Model 1 from a another TRS-80 equiped with min-disk. All the controled TRS-80 model 1 must be equiped with Level II. <br><br> It cost 2895fr (France, 1981)<

Network II box|||p/n 26-1211|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;NETWORK II BOX</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;p/n 26-1211</strong><br><blockquote>This box allowed up to 16 TRS computer to be networked. Three network boxes were released by Tandy (I, II and III).<br> The Network II required verbal communication between the server operator and the remote user, and data transfer had to be completed one user at a time.<br> The network III allowed automated control of the network so that users could easily access programs and data stored on the server's storage device.<

Daisy Wheel Printer II|||Serial# 26-1158|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;DAISY WHEEL PRINTER II</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Serial# 26-1158</strong><br><blockquote>This is a high-quality printer meant to be used with wordprocessors. Some interchangeable daisy-wheels were available (Courrier, Elite, Madeleine). It could print 163 characters per line (34cm), at a 43 cps rate. <br><br> It cost 9595fr (France, 1981)<

Line Printer I |||Ref# 26-7017|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;LINE PRINTER I </strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Ref# 26-7017</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a custom version of the Oki Microline 80.<br> Printed lower and upper case on paper rolls or listing paper (24cm wide) from 40 to 80 columns/line, at a speed rate of 28 lines/minute. <br><br> It cost 716 Euros in 1981 (France).<

Line Printer III|||Serial# 26-1156|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;LINE PRINTER III</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Serial# 26-1156</strong><br><blockquote>This printer can print lower and upper case, at a speed rate of 120 c/s, on paper up to 38cm wide. It is conceived for intensive use ! <br<<br> It cost 9950fr in 1981 (France). <

Line Printer VI|||Serial# 26-1166|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;LINE PRINTER VI</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Serial# 26-1166</strong><br><blockquote>This large printer can print lower and upper case, graphic characters and symbols at a speed rate of 100 c/s ! This is definately a professional printer. <br><br> It cost 5495fr in 1981 (France).<

Exatron |||Stringy Floppy drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;EXATRON </strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Stringy Floppy drive</strong><br><blockquote>The Exatron Stringy Floppy (ESF) was a low-cost data—storage system that fitted the gap, between cassettes and disk drives.<br> The system was based on a miniature endless—loop tape cartridge called a "wafer".<br> The amount of data that could be recorded on a wafer depended on the length of tape in it, typically, a 50—foot wafer could hold at least 40 KB of programs or data. <br><br> <b>Matt</b> reports to us:<br><font color="#666666"> A curiousity about the model 1, CPU SPEED had a direct relatonship with STORAGE CAPACITY. if you doubled the clock speed of your MODEL 1 CPU you doubled the amount of data you could store on your stringy floppies. this is a feat that no other computer no matter how many ghz you have in your PC can do today without using compression.</font> <

computer.keyboard: Typewriter style 83 keys with numeric keypad
computer.name: TRS 80 MODEL 4
computer.ports: Tape (500 or 1500 bauds), Centronics, I/O ports compatible with Model III, Serial (4D)
computer.price: From $1990. In later years the price came down to about $1000By 1990 the Model 4D was being closed out at $599

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;FIRST VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Two Model 4 versions were released. One can recognize them at the surface from the different arrangement of the arrow keys.<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;SECOND VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The second version had an improved gate-array mainboard and a new location for the serial port.<br> The arrow keys are now clustered to the right of the keyboard.<br> This version features a second 3.5" DS DD 720 KB floppy drive (Tandy option). <
<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The red button is the Reset switch<
<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;FRONT PANEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Both FDD drives were Tandon Single-sided, single density models.<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;BOTTOM SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Parallel printer connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Serial connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Expansion port connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Video adjustment<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Tape recorder DIN socket<
<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;INSIDE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The mainboard is mounted vertically at the back.<
<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;INSIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The top cover holds the CRT and its electronics. A fan has been added on top of the CRT.<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;MAINBOARD, 1ST VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The fist mainboard version used only standard chips. It had 64 KB of RAM. Provision was made for a second 64 KB RAM bank.<br> The separate floppy-disk controller card was located behind the mainboard as well as a smal sound generator circuit.<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;MAINBOARD, 2ND VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The second "gate array" version included the floppy-disk controller, the sound generator and buzzer and a second serial port.<br><br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Power connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Video connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Tape recorder connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> 128 KB RAM chips (16x4164 equivalents)<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> WDC1865 UART, serial port controller<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> WD1773 floppy-disk controller<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> BIOS ROMs<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> Z80 CPU socket. In this machine, the CPU chip was replaced by a RAM expansion piggy-back card <br><br> Other chips were custom made for Tandy and had unknown part numbers.<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;RAM CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This RAM card is inserted on the Z80 CPU socket and provides up to 1 MB of extra RAM (2 x 512 KB DIP modules) used as a virtual floppy-disk drive.<
